    38. RangeError: invalid date
    39. SyntaxError: for-in loop head declarations may not have initializers

    42. TypeError: 'x' is not iterable
    43. SyntaxError: JSON.parse: bad parsing
    44. SyntaxError: Malformed formal parameter
    45. URIError: malformed URI sequence

    48. SyntaxError: missing } after function body
    49. SyntaxError: missing } after property list
    50. SyntaxError: missing formal parameter
    51. SyntaxError: missing = in const declaration

    54. SyntaxError: missing ) after condition
    55. SyntaxError: missing ; before statement
    56. TypeError: More arguments needed
    57. RangeError: repeat count must be non-negative
    58. TypeError: "x" is not a non-null object
    59. TypeError: "x" has no properties
    60. SyntaxError: missing variable name
    61. TypeError: can't delete non-configurable array element
    62. RangeError: argument is not a valid code point
    63. TypeError: "x" is not a constructor
    64. TypeError: "x" is not a function
    65. ReferenceError: "x" is not defined
    66. RangeError: precision is out of range
    67. Error: Permission denied to access property "x"
    68. TypeError: "x" is read-only
    69. SyntaxError: redeclaration of formal parameter "x"
    70. TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value
    71. SyntaxError: "x" is a reserved identifier
    72. RangeError: repeat count must be less than infinity
    73. Warning: unreachable code after return statement
    74. SyntaxError: "use strict" not allowed in function with non-simple parameters
    75. InternalError: too much recursion
    76. ReferenceError: assignment to undeclared variable "x"
    77. ReferenceError: reference to undefined property "x"
    78. SyntaxError: Unexpected token

    80. SyntaxError: function statement requires a name
    81. SyntaxError: unparenthesized unary expression can't appear on the left-hand side of '**'
    82. SyntaxError: unterminated string literal

value.content: This chapter documents all the JavaScript language operators, expressions and keywords.

value.title: Expressions and operators by category
value.content: For an alphabetical listing see the sidebar on the left.

value.title: Primary expressions
value.content:
Basic keywords and general expressions in JavaScript.

this

The this keyword refers to a special property of an execution context.

function

The function keyword defines a function expression.

class

The class keyword defines a class expression.

function*

The function* keyword defines a generator function expression.

yield

Pause and resume a generator function.

yield*

Delegate to another generator function or iterable object.

async function

The async function defines an async function expression.

await

Pause and resume an async function and wait for the promise's resolution/rejection.

async function*

The async function* keywords define an async generator function expression.

[]

Array initializer/literal syntax.

{}

Object initializer/literal syntax.

/ab+c/i

Regular expression literal syntax.

( )

Grouping operator.

value.title: Left-hand-side expressions
value.content:
Left values are the destination of an assignment.

Property accessors

Member operators provide access to a property or method of an object (object.property and object["property"]).

new

The new operator creates an instance of a constructor.

new.target

In constructors, new.target refers to the constructor that was invoked by new.

import.meta

An object exposing context-specific metadata to a JavaScript module.

super

The super keyword calls the parent constructor.

...obj

Spread syntax allows an expression to be expanded in places where multiple arguments (for function calls) or multiple elements (for array literals) are expected.

value.title: Increment and decrement
value.content:
Postfix/prefix increment and postfix/prefix decrement operators.

A++

Postfix increment operator.

A--

Postfix decrement operator.

++A

Prefix increment operator.

--A

Prefix decrement operator.

value.title: Unary operators
value.content:
A unary operation is an operation with only one operand.

delete

The delete operator deletes a property from an object.

void

The void operator discards an expression's return value.

typeof

The typeof operator determines the type of a given object.

+

The unary plus operator converts its operand to Number type.

-

The unary negation operator converts its operand to Number type and then negates it.

~

Bitwise NOT operator.

!

Logical NOT operator.

value.title: Arithmetic operators
value.content:
Arithmetic operators take numerical values (either literals or variables) as their operands and return a single numerical value.

+ (Plus)

Addition operator.

-

Subtraction operator.

/

Division operator.

*

Multiplication operator.

%

Remainder operator.

**

Exponentiation operator.

value.title: Relational operators
value.content:
A comparison operator compares its operands and returns a boolean value based on whether the comparison is true.

in

The in operator determines whether an object has a given property.

instanceof

The instanceof operator determines whether an object is an instance of another object.

< (Less than)

Less than operator.

> (Greater than)

Greater than operator.

<=

Less than or equal operator.

>=

Greater than or equal operator.

Note: => is not an operator, but the notation for Arrow functions.

value.title: Equality operators
value.content:
The result of evaluating an equality operator is always of type boolean based on whether the comparison is true.

==

Equality operator.

!=

Inequality operator.

===

Strict equality operator.

!==

Strict inequality operator.

value.title: Bitwise shift operators
value.content:
Operations to shift all bits of the operand.

<<

Bitwise left shift operator.

>>

Bitwise right shift operator.

>>>

Bitwise unsigned right shift operator.

value.title: Binary bitwise operators
value.content:
Bitwise operators treat their operands as a set of 32 bits (zeros and ones) and return standard JavaScript numerical values.

&

Bitwise AND.

|

Bitwise OR.

^

Bitwise XOR.

value.title: Binary logical operators
value.content:
Logical operators are typically used with boolean (logical) values, and when they are, they return a boolean value.

&&

Logical AND.

||

Logical OR.

??

Nullish Coalescing Operator.

value.title: Conditional (ternary) operator
value.content:
(condition ? ifTrue : ifFalse)

The conditional operator returns one of two values based on the logical value of the condition.

value.title: Optional Chaining operator
value.content:
?.

The optional chaining operator returns undefined instead of causing an error if a reference is nullish (null or undefined).

value.title: Assignment operators
value.content:
An assignment operator assigns a value to its left operand based on the value of its right operand.

=

Assignment operator.

*=

Multiplication assignment.

**=

Exponentiation assignment.

/=

Division assignment.

%=

Remainder assignment.

+=

Addition assignment.

-=

Subtraction assignment

<<=

Left shift assignment.

>>=

Right shift assignment.

>>>=

Unsigned right shift assignment.

&=

Bitwise AND assignment.

^=

Bitwise XOR assignment.

|=

Bitwise OR assignment.

&&=

Logical AND assignment.

||=

Logical OR assignment.

??=

Logical nullish assignment.

[a, b] = arr, { a, b } = obj

Destructuring assignment allows you to assign the properties of an array or object to variables using syntax that looks similar to array or object literals.

value.title: Comma operator
value.content:
,

The comma operator allows multiple expressions to be evaluated in a single statement and returns the result of the last expression.

doc.summary: This chapter documents all the JavaScript language operators, expressions and keywords.
